title: Kaggle's Titanic: Machine Learning From Disaster Challenge
content:
My first attempt at a Kaggle competition which is a simple Binary Classification problem or predicting Survival by learning from the RMS Titanic Passengers' Dataset. The steps taken in this project were mainly: Data Cleaning & Validation to ensure the data was clean, complete and valid; Explatory Data Analysis (EDA) to better understand and create relevant features; and Model Selection and Parameter Tuning to select the model best suitable for this Binary Classification task.

Results: Majority Voting Classifier scoring ~0.779.

title: Personal Portfolio
content: The repository for this portfolio website that uses React.js. This website was made as a quick way to showcase my projects and my ability as a web developer. As I update this site, there will be hopefully be more display of my skills. This repository will attempt to display some demonstration of API consumption by mimicking json data to dynamically "alter" the content of this page.

title: A Focal Tracking System Design
content:
This project was done as a summer research project and part of my final year in university. The aim of the project is to design an optical system that is able to maintain the focal plane by driving a tunable lens using a feedback loop of the acquired image - essentially develop a computationally cheap and small real-time auto-focus system.

Behind the technicalities, the methods primarily involved in this project included: Image Processing, Signal Processing methods and Optimization algorithms.

title: Autonomous Racer - ALBiR 2019
content: Part of my final year in university this module and project involved creating an autonomous racer using a Raspberry Pi3 and a Pixy2 Camera. This is the code that won my team 1st place in the final race. This project involved using Python to program the autonomous racer. However for the remainder of the module, Matlab was also used to simulate pursuit tracking amongst other simulations.
